repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

did.langmaterial: Materials are in English and Yiddish.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by James H. Williams in 2002; additional materials were donated by Williams in 2010. The accession number associated with these gifts are 2002.012.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Sandra Gordon Patrinos (1941-2000) was a peace and social justice activist in Chicago. Born in Philadelphia, as a youth the worked with Youth Marches for Integrated School and with "Teens Ahead," which sponsored interracial dances at the YWCA, and later, she became the Communist Party USA's District Organizer for its Eastern Pennsylvania / Delaware district. Patrinos also served on the Party's National Committee. In 1991, the year of the fall of the Soviet Union, she joined the Committees of Correspondence, founded by dissident (democratic-socialist oriented) CPUSA members inspired by the reforms of Mikhail Gorbachev, the last leader of the Soviet Union, and several U.S. leftists. In 1994 the organization changed its name to the Committees of Correspondence for Democracy and Socialism, and Patrinos served on its National Coordinating Committee.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Sandra Gordon Patrinos Papers; TAM 202; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This unprocessed collection contains materials pertaining to the political activities of Sandra Gordon Patrinos, including peace and social justice activism, and the crisis within the Communist Party USA that led to the founding of the Committees of Correspondence.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Approximately 75 buttons were separated to the Tamiment Library Button and Pin Collection (BUTTONS 001).

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Any rights (including copyright and related rights to publicity and privacy) held by Sandra Gordon Patrinos were transferred to New York University in 2002 by James H. Williams. Permission to publish or reproduce materials in this collection must be secured from the Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive. Please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu.
